text: Directive 2008/50/EC, or the Ambient Air Quality Directive, is an EU directive which limits sulphur dioxide, NO2 and other oxides of nitrogen, particulate matter (PM10, PM2,5), lead, benzene and carbon monoxide emissions from 2010. Hourly average emissions of NO2 are limited 200 μg/m3 and yearly to 40 μg/m3. several EU member states are being sued for violating the limits: France, Spain, Italy, Hungary, Romania, Slovakia, the Czech Republic, the United Kingdom and Germany. On 15 February 2018, five member countries were urged to safeguard public health. On 22 February 2018, Poland was found guilty of violating the emission limits in the Radom, Pruszków-Żyrardów and Kędzierzyn- Koźle and Ostrów-Kępno districts during the eight-year period from 2007 to 2015.Court of Justice of the European Union, The Court of Justice finds that Poland has infringed EU law on ambient air quality: Judgment in Case C-336/16 Commission v Poland, published Luxembourg, 22 February 2018, accessed 24 October 2019 ==See also== * TA Luft, a set of laws which implement the directive in Germany *NOx, a generic term for the nitrogen oxides which are most relevant for air pollution ==References== Category:European Union directives Category:2008 in law Category:2008 in the European Union Category:2010 in law Category:2010 in the European Union Category:Environmental law in the European Union
